importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The year 2015 marks the signing of the Paris Climate Agreement, which is central to the study's comparison of climate outcomes before and after the agreement.
The study uses climate data from 1991 to 2020 as a baseline for defining 'superhot days', with projections extending to 2100.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The study projects future increases in superhot days up to 2100, with current trends already showing measurable effects by 2025.

keyTakeAways: The world is on track to add 57 superhot days per year by 2100 due to climate change, a significant but reduced increase from the worst-case scenario of 114 days under pre-Paris warming.
Before the Paris Climate Agreement, the world faced a catastrophic 4°C warming, which would have led to 114 additional superhot days annually.
Since 2015, the world has already added 11 average superhot days, indicating real-world climate impacts are already occurring.

The increase in superhot days is highly unequal: small, ocean-dependent nations like Panama, the Solomon Islands, and Samoa face the largest spikes, with Panama projected to gain 149 extra days annually.
These 10 most affected countries produce only 1% of global carbon emissions, highlighting a profound disconnect between pollution and heat exposure.
The top carbon-emitting countries—U.S., China, and India—despite being responsible for 42% of global CO2 emissions, face only 23–30 extra superhot days, underscoring climate injustice.
The unequal impact of climate change may exacerbate global inequities and fuel geopolitical instability.

namedEntities.name: World Weather Attribution
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A research organization that conducts climate attribution studies to assess the impact of climate change on extreme weather events.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This entity led the study that calculates how climate change is increasing superhot days globally, providing scientific attribution of extreme heat to human-caused warming.

namedEntities.name: Climate Central
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A U.S.-based non-profit organization focused on climate science communication and research.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Climate Central is a key collaborator in the study, contributing to the analysis and dissemination of climate change impacts through established scientific methods.

namedEntities.name: Paris Climate Agreement
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An international treaty adopted in 2015 to limit global warming to well below 2°C, with efforts to keep it below 1.5°C.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The study compares climate outcomes before and after the Paris Agreement, showing how commitments under the agreement reduced projected warming and superhot days.

namedEntities.name: Potsdam Climate Institute
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A research institute under the German Academy of Sciences Leopoldina, focused on climate science and policy.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Potsdam Climate Institute’s Director, Johan Rockstrom, provides an independent expert perspective on the risks of continued warming despite current commitments.

namedEntities.name: Friederike Otto
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A climate scientist at Imperial College London and coauthor of the study.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She provides scientific insight into the human toll of extreme heat, estimating that tens of thousands or millions will be affected by additional superhot days.

namedEntities.name: Andrew Weaver
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A climate scientist at the University of Victoria and an independent expert on climate justice.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He highlights the geopolitical risks of climate inequality, arguing that unequal exposure to heat could deepen global divides.

namedEntities.name: Panama
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A small, coastal nation in Central America, one of the countries most affected by rising heat.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Panama is projected to experience 149 extra superhot days annually, reflecting how vulnerable small island and coastal nations are to climate change despite minimal emissions.

namedEntities.name: Solomon Islands
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A small, ocean-dependent nation in the South Pacific, highly vulnerable to climate change.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Solomon Islands is among the top 10 countries facing the largest increase in superhot days, illustrating climate injustice in small island states.

namedEntities.name: Samoa
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A small, low-lying island nation in the South Pacific, highly exposed to climate change impacts.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Samoa ranks among the top 10 nations with the greatest projected increase in dangerous heat days, emphasizing disproportionate vulnerability.

namedEntities.name: United States
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The largest emitter of greenhouse gases among developed nations.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The U.S. is among the top carbon-polluting countries but faces only a small number of additional superhot days, highlighting a disconnect between emissions and heat exposure.

namedEntities.name: China
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The largest emitter of greenhouse gases globally, responsible for a significant share of global carbon dioxide emissions.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: China is projected to face only 23–30 extra superhot days, despite being responsible for 42% of global CO2 emissions, illustrating climate inequality.

namedEntities.name: India
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major emitter of greenhouse gases and a rapidly developing economy.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: India is projected to see only 23–30 extra superhot days, despite contributing significantly to global carbon emissions, showing a clear mismatch between pollution and heat exposure.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A new study by World Weather Attribution and Climate Central finds that global warming, driven by human activity, will result in an additional 57 superhot days per year by 2100—nearly two months of dangerous heat—thanks to current climate commitments under the Paris Agreement. This represents a significant reduction from the 114 superhot days predicted in a worst-case scenario without the agreement. Since 2015, the world has already added 11 average superhot days. The study reveals a stark global disparity: small, ocean-dependent nations like Panama, the Solomon Islands, and Samoa, which produce negligible emissions, are expected to face the largest spikes in heat, with Panama projected to gain 149 extra days annually. In contrast, top polluters such as the U.S., China, and India, which account for 42% of global CO2, face only 23–30 additional days. Experts warn that this imbalance not only reflects climate injustice but may also contribute to geopolitical tensions, as vulnerable nations bear the brunt of warming while emitters remain largely insulated from its impacts.
title: Climate study finds overheating world will add 57 superhot days a year
